children: In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to simplify and solve systems of linear equations using **elementary row operations**. You‚Äôll also explore the different types of solution structures: unique, infinite, and no solutions ‚Äî and how to identify them systematically.
This is the foundation for methods like **Gaussian elimination** and understanding the **rank** and **consistency** of a system.
By the end of this lesson, you will:

children.children: Use augmented matrices to represent systems of linear equations.
Apply the three elementary row operations to transform a matrix.
Recognize row-echelon form and its role in solving systems.
Identify whether a system has a unique solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solution.
Interpret free variables and express infinite solutions using parameters.

children: A system of linear equations can be represented as an **augmented matrix**, which combines the coefficients and constants into a single structure.

We can manipulate the rows of an augmented matrix using three **elementary row operations**, which do **not change the solution set**:

children.children: **Row Swap**: Exchange two rows. For example, swap row 1 and row 2: **$ R_1 \leftrightarrow R_2 $**
**Row Scaling**: Multiply a row by a nonzero constant. For example, double row 3: **$ R_3 \leftarrow 2R_3 $**
**Row Replacement**: Add a multiple of one row to another. For example: **$ R_2 \leftarrow R_2 - 2R_1 $**

children: ‚úÖ These operations help us transform the matrix into simpler forms ‚Äî like **row-echelon form** or **reduced row-echelon form** ‚Äî where solutions become obvious.
A matrix is in **row-echelon form** if:

children.children: All nonzero rows are above any rows of all zeros
Each leading entry (first nonzero) of a row is to the right of the leading entry above it
All entries below a leading entry are zero

children: After applying row operations, we can determine the **solution structure** of the system.
If every variable corresponds to a **leading 1** (pivot), and there are no contradictions, the system has **exactly one solution**.
If there is at least one **free variable** (a column without a pivot), the system has **infinitely many solutions**.
